pros: Remote; nonprofit; good leadership; great people I am grateful that I work at TMF because my team is professional and always friendly. We actually laugh during meetings. We like each other and feel respected by leadership. What I like most about working at TMF is that I feel valued and that is continually reinforced by my supervisor and colleagues. People appreciate good work and tell you so. There is a company culture of celebrating success and giving kudos to employees. It’s positive and encouraging. TMF has given yearly raises, bonuses, nice corporate gifts, and PTO to show appreciation. Overall, it’s a very nice place to work.
cons: There may be limited growth opportunity, depending on department, for those looking to advance up a career ladder. If you’re looking for something young, flashy, exciting, this may not be your fit.

job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Austin, TX
pros: The benefits are almost unbeatable. Great 401k match, decent health insurance plans, and plenty of paid-time-off. The pay is below-market, although some of the benefits can outway this, depending on your situation.
cons:
What is your favorite part about being a programmer? Is it writing code? Management brings in every 3rd party tool they can find so that programmers don't need to write code. Expect to be creating workflows in drag-and-drop style editors, instead of solving fun problems with code.

Do you like micro-management, with requirements to fill out daily work logs and timesheets, on top of detailed helpdesk resolution statements? Expect nothing less.

Speaking of helpdesk, do you enjoy working tickets about users who forgot their password and can't login to a website? Your day will be full of them.

How do you feel about unrealistic timelines set by business leaders, and managers who can't understand why you never get projects done in time? Look forward to this happening with every project!

Do you enjoy entering your password and 2FA 30+ times per day, including multiple times per logon session? Well then you'll love the poorly implemented and over-bearing security protocols.

Do you like setting career goals with your manager, and making improvements to your skillset in order to progress up the ladder? Too bad, and good luck. You'll likely be stuck in your hired position for 10 years with minimal pay raises.

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Tampa, FL
pros: Caring, Understanding, Attentive, Dedicated, Friendly
cons: Nothing bad to say about them

job_title: Quality Improvement Consultant in Tulsa, OK
pros: Leadership, treat employees as capable professionals, independence, communication
cons: Little opportunity for career advancement

review_title: The best job that I have ever had
pros: In my experience, TMF hires based primarily on the canidate's fit with company culture.  I had little experience in the health quality world, but was give an opportunity, which has morphed into to best job of my adult life.  TMF operates o "big kids rules", that is, there is alot of flexibility for remote employees, where you design your own workflow, which is allowable as long as the work gets done on time and with good outcomes.  It's not for everyone, to be sure, but there are alot worse things in life than being paid to be creative.  The pay is less than in the clinical realm, but the benefits and flexibility more than compensate.  Plus, the company places a premium on work-life balance, which was new to me after many years in clinical practice. 60% percent of our company works remotely, so you have to be naturally organized to be effective and successful.
cons: I haven't found any deal breakers to date.  There are minor process issues that arise, but none that have ever interfered with receipt of pay or benefits.  The organizational structure is horizontal, so if you are looking to "climb the corporate ladder", you will not find that at TMF.  Achievement is rewarded, but in different ways, such as education benefits, generous bonuses and profit sharing, and non-financial means, such as the ability to help make the world a better place on a large scale, and spend time enjoying life.

pros: Culture..everyone is really friendly and it has a laidback environment.
cons: Low pay, expect you too do extra work outside your payrate. The IT system is atrocious. Constant problems literally everyday with the system freezing, not responding, disconnecting especially when working from home. The IT staff must be totally incompetent because none of these issues have yet to be fixed and have been going on for what seems like forever. At one point the whole system went down for a day and they expected us to use our sick hours to make up for the time or work on the weekend instead. Your productivity goes down the crapper because you can't get any work done with their shoddy IT system.

job_title: Quality Improvement Consultant in Austin, TX
pros: I work with Texas Nursing Homes and we work to improve quality of care for all residents. I have full support of a team and the homes are very receptive to the ideas I bring them. I make a difference in the lives of residents on a daily basis. This is a very rewarding position.
cons: NONE! I just wish I had found this position earlier in my career, but that's on me!
